Read the writing task and look carefully at the diagram. Complete the report by filling each gap with a word, phrase or number taken from the diagram. You will need to use some of the words more than once.
Writing Task 1

section.p: The water-balanced railway basically operates like a huge balance, using the difference in weight between the two carriages to transport passengers up and down a hillside metres in height.

The carriages are made of so that they are light and strong. Underneath each one is a , which carries up to litres of water. The carriages run along metres of parallel steel track and are linked by steel cables. These go around a large at the top of the slope.

When one carriage is at the top of the hill, the other is at the bottom. The ballast tank underneath the top carriage is filled with water from a so as to make it slightly heavier than the lower carriage. Due to this imbalance, the top one begins to roll down the hill, pulling the other one up. A weighs each carriage in order to gauge exactly how much water is needed to make them move. Speed is controlled by means of a built into the at the top. This consists of a , which slows the drum down if it is turning too fast, causing the carriages to reduce speed. Each time this happens, the system compresses in special cylinders. As a result, some of the energy of braking is stored. This can later be used to a proportion of the water back up to the . Consequently, some energy is recycled. The water-balanced railway is an excellent example of how renewable energy sources can be used to power a transport system.
